Graphical abstract M4/Nb2O5 catalysts were designed for the selective hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol. Guaiacol is converted to cyclohexanol on Ru4/Nb2O5 and Pt4/Nb2O5 surfaces, while fully deoxygenated products (benzene and cyclohexane) are obtained over Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Ir4/Nb2O5. Guaiacol hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), a key reaction in lignin valorization, enables the production of high-octane, low-oxygen compounds such as benzene and cyclohexane. However, precise control over product selectivity remains a main challenge due to the complex reaction network. In this work, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were employed to investigate the mechanism and product selectivity of guaiacol HDO over five metal clusters supported on Nb2O5 (M4/Nb2O5, M = Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, Pt). The results show that Ru4 and Pt4 clusters preferentially stabilize the adsorption of aromatic rings, thereby facilitating ring hydrogenation to form cyclohexanol. In contrast, Rh4/Nb2O5 and Pd4/Nb2O5 promote selective C–O bond cleavage with limited ring hydrogenation, favoring the formation of benzene. Notably, Ir4/Nb2O5 enables complete ring hydrogenation and C–OH bond cleavage, resulting in the formation of cyclohexane as the main product. Experimental results confirmed that Pd/Nb2O5 and Ir/Nb2O5 catalyze the conversion of guaiacol to fully deoxygenated products (benzene and cyclohexane), with a conversion rate of 70 %. The correlation study has confirmed that the electronegativity of metal clusters strongly affects the activity and selectivity of the reaction through the synergistic effect between the metal and the support. These findings elucidate the structure–activity–selectivity relationships underlying HDO performance and offer valuable insights for the rational design of selective deoxygenation catalysts targeting lignin-derived compounds. Keywords Biomass catalytic conversion Hydrodeoxygenation Guaiacol Metal-supported interactions Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The over-exploitation of fossil resources has led to numerous challenges, including the energy crisis and environmental degradation. [1–3] Lignocellulose, a renewable and environmentally friendly biomass feedstock, has attracted significant attention. [3–6] Lignin, the primary component of lignocellulosic biomass, accounts for 15–40 % of weight and is the most abundant renewable aromatic energy source, with considerable application potential for various applications. [7,8] Traditional lignin conversion methods, such as pyrolysis, hydrolysis, and reductive depolymerization, often yield bio-oils with low energy density and unstable combustion properties, limiting use in biofuels and value-added chemicals. [9,10] In contrast, Hydrogenation (HDO) technology has been shown to enhance the quality of pyrolysis products, particularly in heterogeneous catalytic systems. [11–13] Guaiacol, a typical lignin pyrolysis product, contains strong Caryl−OR (R: H, CH3) bonds and a benzene ring structure. [14,15] HDO reactions can produce high-value products, such as cyclohexane, benzene, and cyclohexanol. [16,17] Benzene and cyclohexane, with low-oxygen content and high-octane rating, are especially valuable as fuel additives. [15,18] However, selectively cleaving Caryl − OR bonds and hydrogenating the benzene ring in guaiacol remain significant challenges. Developing a highly active and selective catalytic system is of great importance for precisely controlling the cleavage of the Caryl − OR bond or the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, thereby enabling targeted modulation of product distribution in HDO reactions. Recent studies highlight the widespread use of metal-supported catalysts in lignin HDO reactions due to excellent stability, activity, and selectivity. [1,19,20] Commonly used metals include Pt, Pd, Rh, and Ru, as noble metal catalysts are more effective than non-noble metals in promoting H2 dissociation and activating C − O bonds. [11,21–23] Additionally, catalyst supports with acidic sites, such as Al2O3, Nb2O5, and ZrO2, have garnered attention for strong redox properties, tunable structures, and low toxicity, among which Nb2O5 stands out due to particularly favorable characteristics. [24–26] Shao and colleagues demonstrated that Nb2O5 catalysts show superior adsorption of phenolic compounds compared to TiO2 and ZrO2. [25] Moreover, Nb2O5 can deprotonate phenolic compounds, forming phenoxy species that facilitate the cleavage of Caryl − OH bonds. [27] Nb has a strong affinity for oxygen, forming Nb − O − Nb species, which enhances electron transfer in the carbonyl group and promotes C − O bond cleavage. The interaction between Nb2O5 and active metals creates a stable interface, preventing agglomeration and improving catalyst stability. Furthermore, the synergy between Nb2O5 and active metals significantly accelerates the catalytic reaction rate. As a result, Nb2O5-supported bifunctional catalysts are widely used in lignin HDO. [28–30]. Herein, we employ density functional theory (DFT) calculations to systematically investigate the HDO of guaiacol over a series of M4/Nb2O5 catalysts (M = Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, Pt), aiming to achieve tunable product selectivity toward benzene, cyclohexanol, or cyclohexane. The role of metal-support interactions in modulating C–O bond activation and aromatic ring hydrogenation is clarified by analyzing interfacial electronic structures and reaction energetics. To establish predictive relationships between catalyst properties and performance, we further introduce two composite descriptors and perform correlation analyses. Guided by theoretical insights, Pd/Nb2O5 and Ir/Nb2O5 catalysts were synthesized and experimentally evaluated, showing product distributions consistent with DFT predictions. This work highlights the critical role of interfacial structure in steering HDO reaction pathways and provides a data-driven framework for the rational design of bifunctional catalysts for selective biomass upgrading. 2 Computational methods 2.1 Computational detail Spin-polarized periodic DFT calculations were performed by the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP 5.4.1). [31,32] The projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe electron–ion interactions. [33,34] Electron exchange–correlation interactions were modeled using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional. [35] The Grimme’s DFT–D3 method was added to consider the effect of van der Waals interactions. [36] A cutoff energy of 400 eV for the plane-wave basis sets and a 3 × 3 × 1 grid generated by the Monkhorst − Pack method were adopted for all calculations. The convergence criteria for the electronic self-consistent convergence and forces were set to 10–4 eV and 0.05 eV/Å. The transition states (TSs) were obtained using the Dimer method and the climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method. [37,38] Only one imaginary vibrational frequency was observed, confirming the TS's structure along the reaction coordinate of the pathway. The stabilities of the Nb2O5 (001) surfaces are characterized by surface energies γ, defined by [39] (1) γ = ( E slab - N E bulk ) 2 A where E slab is the total energy of the slab, E bulk is the total energy of one unit cell of the bulk, N is the number of bulk unit cells in the slab, and A is the surface area of one side of the slab. The binding energy (E BE) of M4 was calculated by eq2: (2) E BE = E total - E slab - E M 4 Where E total is the electronic energy of the surface containing the M4 cluster, E slab is the electronic energy of the Nb2O5 surface, and E M4 is the electronic energy of the M4 cluster. The adsorption energy of each adsorbate (E ads) was calculated by eq3: (3) E ads = E slab + a d s o r b a t e - E slab - E adsorbate Where E slab+adsorbate is the total energy after adsorption, E slab is the energy of the clean slab before adsorption, and E adsorbate is the energy of the free adsorbate in the gas phase. The reaction energy barrier (E b) was calculated by eq4: (4) E b = E TS - E IS Where E IS and E TS are the energies of the initial state (IS) and transition state, respectively. 2.2 Model Building In this study,Nb2O5 was used as the support, with the optimal exposed crystal surface being (001). The slab consisted of three layers with p (3 × 3) periodic unit cells for the Nb2O5. The M4 (M4 = Ru4, Rh4, Pd4, Ir4, and Pt4) metal cluster was supported on the Nb2O5 (001) surface due to unique electronic structure and high surface atomic density. [40–42] A vacuum space of 15 Å was added on the surfaces to avoid interactions between slabs, as shown in Fig. S1 . The ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were performed at reaction temperature of 453.15 K in a canonical ensemble with constant volume and constant temperature (NVT) employing the Nose-Hoover thermostats with a time step of 1.0 fs. [43,44] The optimized geometries obtained from DFT calculations were used as the initial configurations for AIMD simulations. The AIMD simulations were carried out for 10 ps to ensure that the simulated system reached an equilibrium state. 2.3 Experimental section Preparation of Pd/Nb2O5 and Ir/Nb2O5. Firstly, 0.5 g of Nb2O5 was dispersed in 50 ml of deionised water with the addition of 1.146 ml of 0.035 mol/L (NH4)2PdCl4 solution. The resulting dispersion was stirred for 12 h, then dried overnight at 60°C in an oven. Next, 0.5 g of the mixture was calcined at 500°C for 3 h in a muffle furnace (heating rate: 5°C/min), then cooled to room temperature to obtain Pd/Nb2O5 samples. A similar procedure was followed to immobilize Ir on Nb2O5 with H2Cl6Ir as precursor. Catalytic Evaluations. The hydrodeoxygenation reactions of guaiacol were performed in a 25 mL stainless-steel batch reactor. The reaction mixture comprised 0.2 mL of guaiacol, 0.03 g of catalyst, and 9 mL of isopropanol. Afterwards, the reactor was purged completely by 3.0 MPa H2 (>99.999 %) for five rounds and finally charged with pure H2 at 2.0 MPa, and heated to 180°C. Product yields were analyzed using a Shimadzu GC-2014C gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector. To evaluate stability, five reaction cycles were carried out. After each cycle, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed three times with ethanol, and reused without further treatment. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1  M4/Nb2O5 surfaces analysis To elucidate the interactions between metal clusters and the Nb2O5 support, we systematically analyzed the electronic and structural properties of five M4/Nb2O5 catalysts. The surface energy of the Nb2O5 (001) facet was calculated to assess its stability, giving a value of 1.391 J/m2, which is relatively low and highlights the structural stability of this surface. The binding energies of the five metal clusters anchored on the Nb2O5 surface range from − 3.30 eV (Pd4/Nb2O5) to − 6.05 eV (Ir4/Nb2O5), indicating varied interfacial strengths and confirming strong metal–support interactions (Fig. 1a  − e). To further verify its thermal stability, we performed AIMD simulations for M4/Nb2O5, as shown in Fig. S2 . After a 10.0 ps AIMD run (AIMD evolved by 10 × 103 steps with a step length of 1.0 fs), the structure of the M4/Nb2O5 system remained stable without bond breaking, and the energy fluctuations were minimal. The AIMD results suggest that M4/Nb2O5 has an exceedingly high stability at reaction temperature of 453.15 K. Bader charge analysis of the M4 clusters further reveals that the interfacial metal atoms exhibit reduced charge accumulation, whereas the top-layer metal atoms show more pronounced charge accumulation in Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, Ir4/Nb2O5, and Pt4/Nb2O5 ( Fig. S3 ). Notably, the Ir and Pt clusters, with their higher electronegativity and ionization energies, exhibit increased negative charge on both interfacial and top atoms. In contrast, the relatively low electronegativity and first ionization energy of Ru result in positively charged interfacial atoms and negatively charged top atoms within the Ru4 cluster. The projected density of states (PDOS) reveals remarkable orbital hybridization between the M4 clusters and the Nb2O5 support near the Fermi level, indicative of strong metal–support interactions (Fig. 1 f–j). The calculated d-band centers of the noble metals range from –1.52 to –2.15 eV. Among them, Ru4/Nb2O5 is located closest to the Fermi level, consistent with its higher reactivity, whereas Pt4/Nb2O5 is farthest. Rh4, Pd4, and Ir4 clusters exhibit similar d-band center positions, suggesting comparable reaction characteristics. These results reveal the diverse metal–support interfacial electronic properties, which are expected to influence catalytic behavior. 3.2 Adsorption structure analysis of guaiacol. We further analyzed the adsorption configurations of guaiacol on the M4/Nb2O5 systems. The optimized adsorption structures on the five M4 cluster (Ru4, Rh4, Pd4, Ir4, and Pt4) and Nb2O5 interfaces show that the aromatic ring of guaiacol interacts with the metal atoms in the M4 cluster through M–π bonds, while the oxygen atoms in the –OCH3 and –OH groups form Nb–O bonds with the Nb2O5 support. Charge density difference shows strong interactions between the π electrons of the aromatic ring and the metal atoms in the M4 clusters, along with notable Nb–O interactions between the Nb atoms and the oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) in guaiacol ( Fig. S4 ). Bader charge analysis shows that the C1, C6, and C7 atoms gain electrons, which are closest to the Nb2O5 surface, whereas the C2, C3, C4, and C5 atoms lose electrons (Table 1 ). Differences in electronegativity and first ionization energy cause the supported metal clusters to carry negative charges, which in turn influence the adsorption structure and energy of guaiacol on the five catalysts (Fig. 2 ). At the Ru4/Nb2O5 interface, which carries only a slight positive charge, guaiacol exhibits the strongest adsorption (–1.70 eV) due to pronounced interactions between the aromatic ring and the Ru4 cluster. In contrast, Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, Ir4/Nb2O5, and Pt4/Nb2O5, which carry more negative charges, interact more weakly with guaiacol, with adsorption energies of –0.93, –0.88, –0.91, and –0.94 eV, respectively. On Pt4/Nb2O5, adsorption primarily involves interactions between the aromatic ring and the metal cluster. By contrast, on Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Ir4/Nb2O5, adsorption occurs through both M–π interactions with the aromatic ring and Nb–O bonding between guaiacol oxygen atoms and the Nb2O5 support. On the pure Nb2O5 surface, guaiacol adsorbs only weakly, with energies of 0.17 eV (flat) and 0.56 eV (tilted) ( Fig. S5 ). These results indicate that guaiacol adsorbs much more strongly at the M4/Nb2O5 interfaces than on the Nb2O5 surface. To further probe the bonding strength of the C–OCH3 and C–OH, crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) analysis was performed. A more negative ICOHP value corresponds to stronger bonding between C and O. As shown in Fig. S6 , the C–OH bond exhibits a more negative ICOHP value than the C–OCH3 bond, indicating that the C–OH bond is stronger. This result suggests that the C–OCH3 bond is more prone to cleavage than the C–OH bond. Based on the adsorption structures, we propose that hydrogenation of the aromatic ring is more favorable on Ru4/Nb2O5 and Pt4/Nb2O5, whereas C–O bond cleavage is more favorable on Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Ir4/Nb2O5. Although the M4 cluster model was employed in this study to represent the metal-support interface, it is recognized that real catalysts may contain larger nanoparticles with a broader distribution of surface sites, including terraces and step edges. Previous theoretical and experimental studies have established that, in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of phenolic compounds, C–O bond cleavage is generally more favorable at the metal-support interface than on extended metal surfaces, owing to synergistic electronic and geometric effects. [45–47]. To probe the potential influence of cluster size on Nb2O5, we performed test calculations using Ru/Nb2O5 as a model catalyst with slightly larger clusters (M6 and M8). The results show that the Ru atoms at the interfacial sites carry a positive charge, whereas those at the top are negatively charged, which is consistent with Ru4/Nb2O5 ( Fig. S7 ). Adsorption structures further reveal that guaiacol adopts qualitatively similar geometries on Ru6/Nb2O5 and Ru8/Nb2O5 as on Ru4/Nb2O5, with interfacial binding of the C–OCH3 and C–OH groups being most favorable. The corresponding adsorption energies are –1.50 eV (Ru6/Nb2O5) and –1.63 eV (Ru8/Nb2O5), both weaker than that at the Ru4/Nb2O5 interface ( Fig. S8 ). With increasing cluster size, however, guaiacol adsorption becomes progressively biased toward the metal cluster surface. Because the interaction of the C–OCH3 and C–OH groups with Nb2O5 is relatively weak, these groups are only weakly activated, and their C–O bond lengths remain shorter than those observed for guaiacol adsorption on Ru4/Nb2O5. Consequently, this adsorption structure favors hydrogenation of the aromatic ring over C–O bond scission, thereby suppressing the formation of fully deoxygenated products. Taken together with prior reports, these results highlight that the mechanistic insights and selectivity trends derived from the M4 model are qualitatively robust. 3.3 Reaction mechanism of guaiacol on M4/Nb2O5 surfaces The HDO reaction mechanism of guaiacol generally follows four pathways, as shown in Scheme 1 : direct deoxygenation (DDO), where the C–O bond (1Caryl–OH, 2Calkyl–OAr, and 3Caryl–OCH3) is cleaved via hydrogenation while the aromatic ring remains unsaturated; 4Hydrogenation followed by deoxygenation (HDO), where hydrogenation of the aromatic ring is hydrogenated before C–O bond cleavage. On the M4/Nb2O5 surface, the adsorption configurations show that –CH3 groups are positioned away from the catalyst surface, resulting in spatial repulsion that hinders the cleavage of the Calkyl–OAr bond. Therefore, this study focuses on the competition between Caryl–OH and Caryl–OCH3 cleavage and the hydrogenation of the benzene ring in guaiacol. 3.3.1 HDO reaction mechanism of guaiacol on Ru4/Nb2O5 and Pt4/Nb2O5 surfaces Previous studies have shown that the initial hydrogenation of the benzene ring is the most challenging, while subsequent hydrogenation steps exhibit lower energy barriers. [48,49] Therefore, we focused on the comparison of the energy barriers for the first-step hydrogenation and the cleavage of C–OCH3 and C–OH bonds. Fig. 3 shows the potential energy diagrams of the guaiacol HDO reaction on the Ru4/Nb2O5 and Pt4/Nb2O5 surfaces. The energy barriers on the Ru4/Nb2O5 surface are 0.78 eV for the initial hydrogenation of guaiacol, 1.11 eV for C–OCH3 bond cleavage, and 1.30 eV for C–OH bond cleavage. The corresponding values on the Pt4/Nb2O5 surface are 1.35, 1.72, and 1.85 eV, respectively. In both cases, the barrier for the first hydrogenation step is significantly lower than that for C–OCH3 or C–OH bond cleavage, indicating that the formation of the partially hydrogenated intermediate, 2-methoxycyclohexanol ( Fig. S9 ), is thermodynamically favorable. Owing to the strong oxophilicity of Nb, further cleavage of the C–OCH3 or C–OH bonds is possible. The energy barriers for C–OCH3 bond cleavage on Ru4/Nb2O5 (0.73 eV) and Pt4/Nb2O5 (1.17 eV) are significantly lower than those for C–OH bond cleavage, suggesting a higher probability of C–OCH3 bond scission, which facilitates the formation of cyclohexanol intermediates. Subsequent cleavage of the C–OH bond in cyclohexanol is kinetically hindered, with barriers of 1.50 eV on Ru4/Nb2O5 and 1.57 eV on Pt4/Nb2O5, suggesting that cyclohexanol is likely to be the final product. Notably, for both Ru4/Nb2O5 and Pt4/Nb2O5, the initial hydrogenation step in the conversion of guaiacol to cyclohexanol is identified as the rate-determining step. 3.3.2 HDO reaction mechanism of guaiacol on Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5 and Ir4/Nb2O5 surfaces The adsorption configurations of guaiacol on Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Ir4/Nb2O5 surfaces are similar, with oxygen-containing groups preferentially adsorbed at the Nb site. As shown in Fig. 4 , the energy barriers for the C–OCH3 bond cleavage in guaiacol are 0.73 eV (Rh4/Nb2O5), 1.23 eV (Pd4/Nb2O5), and 1.07 eV (Ir4/Nb2O5), respectively. The energy barriers for C–OH bond cleavage are 1.51 eV, 1.63 eV, and 1.23 eV, respectively. In comparison, the barriers for the initial dehydrogenation step are significantly higher than those for C–O bond cleavage, with energy barrier of 2.16 eV (Rh4/Nb2O5), 2.21 eV (Pd4/Nb2O5), and 1.77 eV (Ir4/Nb2O5), respectively, indicating that hydrogenation of guaiacol is generally unfavorable on these catalysts. Among the potential reaction pathways, the cleavage of the C–OCH3 bond shows the lowest energy barrier, indicating that this step is the most favorable and leads to phenol as the primary intermediate. As shown in Fig. S10 , the intermediate phenol exhibits different adsorption configurations on the Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Ir4/Nb2O5 surfaces, which may result in distinct reaction pathways. On Ir4/Nb2O5 surface, phenol strongly interacts with the aromatic ring. The energy barrier for the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring is 1.33 eV lower than that of C–OH bond cleavage (2.05 eV), indicating that ring hydrogenation is more favorable. Subsequently, the C–OH bond is cleaved with an energy barrier of 1.22 eV, ultimately cyclohexane as the major product. In contrast, on the Rh4/Nb2O5 and Pd4/Nb2O5 surfaces, the adsorption sites for the aromatic ring of phenol are limited and spatially distant, potentially hindering hydrogenation of the ring. The energy barriers for C–OH bond cleavage on Rh4/Nb2O5 and Pd4/Nb2O5 surfaces are 0.96 eV and 0.84 eV, respectively, both of which are lower than those for aromatic ring hydrogenation (1.98 eV and 1.79 eV). This favors the formation of benzene. Due to the high stability by extended π-bonding system, the further hydrogenation of benzene is hindered, resulting in benzene as the predominant product. The rate-determining steps on Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Ir4/Nb2O5 are C–OH bond cleavage, C–OCH3 bond cleavage, and phenol hydrogenation, respectively. 3.4 Selectivity of C–O bond cleavage Although Nb is a key site for C–O bond activation, its activity is significantly affected by the supported M4 metal clusters. As shown in Figs. 5a, c and Table S1 , guaiacol is adsorbed on pure Nb2O5 with a C–OCH3 bond length of 1.38 Å. In contrast, on the Ru4/Nb2O5, Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Ir4/Nb2O5 surfaces, the corresponding C–OCH3 bond lengths are extended to 1.41 Å, 1.42 Å, 1.40 Å, and 1.42 Å, respectively, indicating that the incorporation of Ru4, Rh4, Pd4, and Ir4 clusters effectively promotes the activation of the C–OCH3 bond. Furthermore, the energy barriers for C–OCH3 bond cleavage on metal-supported catalysts are lower than that on pure Nb2O5. However, on Pt4/Nb2O5 surface, the C–OCH3 bond length of adsorbed guaiacol is shortened to 1.37 Å, suggesting that the Pt4 clusters inhibits the activation of the C–OCH3 bond, resulting in a higher activation energy. As shown in Figs. 5b, d and Table S1 , the C–OH bond length of guaiacol adsorbed on Nb2O5 is 1.40 Å. Upon adsorption on Ru4/Nb2O5 and Ir4/Nb2O5, the C–OH bond is elongated to 1.42 Å and 1.45 Å, respectively, indicating bond activation. Consistently, the energy barriers for C–OH bond cleavage are reduced to 1.30 eV (Ru4/Nb2O5) and 1.07 eV (Ir4/Nb2O5), both lower than that on pure Nb2O5 (1.33 eV), demonstrating the promoting effect of Ru4 and Ir4 clusters on C–OH bond activation. In contrast, on Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Pt4/Nb2O5 surface, the energy barriers for C–OH bond dissociation are higher than that on pure Nb2O5, indicating that the incorporation of Rh4, Pd4, and Pt4 clusters have a weaker promoted effect on C–OH bond activation. Figs. 5c and 5d show that the correlation coefficient (R 2) between the C–OCH3 bond length and the corresponding cleavage barrier reaches 0.96, whereas that for the C–OH bond is 0.90. This indicates that the C–OCH3 bond is more sensitive to structural changes than the C–OH bond. Consequently, the activation of the C–OCH3 bond is more strongly influenced by the nature of the supported metal clusters compared to the C–OH bond. 3.5 HDO reactivity and product selectivity In the HDO of guaiacol over M4/Nb2O5 catalysts (M = Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, Pt), the product distribution reflects the differences in the metal clusters’ abilities to activate the aromatic ring, dissociate hydrogen, and modulate the cleavage pathways of interfacial C–OCH3/OH bonds (Scheme 2 ). Rh4/Nb2O5 and Pd4/Nb2O5 catalysts facilitate C–O bond cleavage in guaiacol. However, the relatively weak adsorption of the aromatic ring leads to rapid desorption of the benzene product, thereby inhibiting further hydrogenation. In contrast, Ir4/Nb2O5 effectively disrupts aromaticity and enables complete hydrogenation to cyclohexane. Ru4/Nb2O5 and Pt4/Nb2O5 exhibit stronger adsorption toward aromatic intermediates, allowing for hydrogenation to saturated cyclic structures. Nonetheless, further –OH removal is hindered, resulting in cyclohexanol as the final product. Among the five catalysts, only Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Ir4/Nb2O5 are capable of catalyzing guaiacol to fully deoxygenated products. 3.6 Experimental studies on the catalytic performance of Pd/Nb2O5 and Ir/Nb2O5 catalysts The DFT calculation suggest that Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Ir4/Nb2O5 catalysts can get fully deoxygenated products such as benzene and cyclohexane. To validate these predictions, experimental investigations were performed. Given the similar performance of Rh4/Nb2O5 and Pd4/Nb2O5 in producing benzene, Pd4/Nb2O5 and Ir4/Nb2O5 catalysts were selected for synthesis and evaluation, considering comparative cost-effectiveness. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Pd/Nb2O5 and Ir/Nb2O5 samples show characteristic peaks for high-purity Nb2O5 (2θ = 22.8°, 28.5°, and 29.1°), along with weak peaks at 2θ = 40.1° and 40.6°, attributed to Pd and Ir phases, respectively ( Fig. S11 a). These findings indicate that Pd and Ir species are well dispersed on the Nb2O5 support. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images ( Fig. S11 b − 6c) show nanosheet morphologies for both Pd/Nb2O5 and Ir/Nb2O5, with an average size of ∼ 300 nm. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images and Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) patterns (Fig. 6a  − 6b) confirm a lattice spacing of 0.39 nm, corresponding to the Nb2O5(001) facet in both samples. Pd and Ir clusters are uniformly distributed along the edges of the Nb2O5 nanosheets, consistent with the XRD results. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Fig. 6c − 6d) of the Pd 3d and Ir 4f binding energies shows the coexistence of metallic (Pd0, Ir0) and oxidized (Pd2+, Ir2+) states in both samples, with the metallic state predominating. These characterization results confirm the successful preparation of Pd/Nb2O5 and Ir/Nb2O5 samples. The catalytic performance of Pd/Nb2O5 in the hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol reveals phenol and benzene as the primary products during the initial reaction stages (Fig. 6e). As the reaction progresses, the relative content of phenol decreases while benzene concentration increases, ultimately becoming the dominant product with a selectivity exceeding 70 %. This suggests preferential cleavage of the C–OCH3 bond to form phenol as an intermediate, consistent with the computational results (Fig. 4b). On the Ir/Nb2O5 catalyst, guaiacol initially produces phenol, cyclohexanol, and cyclohexane. Over time, the concentrations of phenol and cyclohexanol decrease, with cyclohexane selectivity surpassing 80 % (Fig. 6f). This indicates that the reaction pathway for guaiacol on Ir4/Nb2O5 involves the cleavage of the C–OCH3 bond to produce phenol, followed by hydrogenation of the benzene ring to cyclohexanol, and ultimately the cleavage of the C–OH bond to form cyclohexane, consistent with the computational results (Fig. 4c). Moreover, both Pd/Nb2O5 and Ir/Nb2O5 catalysts exhibit guaiacol conversion rates exceeding 70 %, highlighting high catalytic efficiency and potential as effective HDO catalysts. We conducted ten consecutive catalytic cycles at the reaction temperature, as shown in Fig. S12 . The results show that the cyclohexane selectivity decreases by less than 3 % after the tenth cycle, indicating excellent catalyst stability. The experimental results align well with theoretical mechanistic predictions, further validating the accuracy of our product selectivity forecast based on theoretical insights. 3.7 Descriptors of activity and selectivity. Refining the descriptors of HDO reactivity and product selectivity is essential for optimizing the structural and electronic properties of multicomponent interfaces to enhance catalytic performance. To elucidate the structure–reactivity relationship in the HDO of guaiacol over M4/Nb2O5 catalysts, we constructed two composite descriptors that captures both structural and electronic contributions to activity and selectivity. The activity descriptor is defined as follows: (1) φ 1 = I 1 × G / χ where I 1 is the first ionization energy, G is the group number of metal atom, χ is electronegativity of metal atom. The selectivity descriptor is defined as follows: (2) φ 2 = d elec + χ 3 where d elec is d electron number of metal atom. As shown in Fig. 7 , the catalytic activity exhibits a strong correlation with φ1 (R2 = 0.85), indicating that a higher first ionization energy coupled with a lower electronegativity favors higher activity ( Table S2 ). In contrast, the reaction selectivity correlates strongly with φ2 (R2 = 0.94), suggesting that metals with more d electrons and higher electronegativity tend to promote greater selectivity. DFT results indicate that the electronegativity of the metal cluster governs reactivity and selectivity by modulating the reaction pathway through interfacial electronic effects. Specifically, the electronegativity of the metal governs the extent of charge redistribution at the metal–support interface, which in turn modifies the adsorption strength of guaiacol on Nb2O5. This effect governs the sequence of hydrogenation and C–O bond cleavage. 4 Conclusion In summary, a comprehensive study combining DFT calculations and experimental validation was conducted to elucidate the adsorption behavior and HDO mechanisms of guaiacol over M4/Nb2O5 (M = Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, Pt) catalysts. Adsorption configuration and reaction pathway investigations show that guaiacol preferentially binds via the aromatic ring on Ru4/Nb2O5 and Pt4/Nb2O5, promoting ring hydrogenation while inhibiting C–O bond cleavage, thereby favoring cyclohexanol as the primary product. In contrast, for Rh4/Nb2O5, Pd4/Nb2O5, and Ir4/Nb2O5, the C–CH3/OH bonds of guaiacol are effectively activated, enabling the formation of fully deoxygenated products. For Rh4/Nb2O5 and Pd4/Nb2O5, benzene is the predominant product owing to the facile desorption of the aromatic intermediate. In contrast, Ir4/Nb2O5 enables further hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, ultimately cyclohexane as the final product. Experimental results further confirmed that Pd/Nb2O5 and Ir/Nb2O5 selectively convert guaiacol to benzene and cyclohexane, respectively, in good agreement with the DFT results. Additionally, the correlation analysis indicates that metal electronegativity strongly influences the reactivity and selectivity of the reaction through the synergistic effect of the metal and support. This study provides valuable insights into the HDO mechanism of guaiacol over M4/Nb2O5 catalysts and offers guidance for the rational design of catalysts with tailored product selectivity. Author contributions S. Wang, Y. Shi, H. Feng, and X. Zhang conceived the conceptualization. S. Wang, Y. Shi, and S. Zhang performed the investigation of DFT calculations. Z. Tian and L. Wang performed the investigation of the experiment. Y. Deng and H. Ding performed the search for the descriptor. The manuscript was primarily written by S. Wang, Y. Shi, Z. Tian and revised by L. Wang, H. Feng, and X. Zhang. All authors discussed the results and commented on the manuscript. CRediT authorship contribution statement Si Wang: Writing – original draft, Software, Methodology, Investigation, Data curation, Conceptualization. Yawen Shi: Investigation, Data curation, Conceptualization. Zhaowei Tian: Writing – original draft, Methodology, Investigation, Data curation. Hu Ding: Investigation, Formal analysis. Yuan Deng: Investigation. Shilong Zhang: Investigation. Lei Wang: Investigation. Haisong Feng: Writing – review & editing, Methodology, Conceptualization. Xin Zhang: Writing – review & editing, Software, Funding acquisition, Conceptualization. coredata.dc:description: Guaiacol hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), a key reaction in lignin valorization, enables the production of high-octane, low-oxygen compounds such as benzene and cyclohexane. However, precise control over product selectivity remains a main challenge due to the complex reaction network. In this work, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were employed to investigate the mechanism and product selectivity of guaiacol HDO over five metal clusters supported on Nb2O5 (M4/Nb2O5, M = Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, Pt). The results show that Ru4 and Pt4 clusters preferentially stabilize the adsorption of aromatic rings, thereby facilitating ring hydrogenation to form cyclohexanol. In contrast, Rh4/Nb2O5 and Pd4/Nb2O5 promote selective C–O bond cleavage with limited ring hydrogenation, favoring the formation of benzene. Notably, Ir4/Nb2O5 enables complete ring hydrogenation and C–OH bond cleavage, resulting in the formation of cyclohexane as the main product. Experimental results confirmed that Pd/Nb2O5 and Ir/Nb2O5 catalyze the conversion of guaiacol to fully deoxygenated products (benzene and cyclohexane), with a conversion rate of 70 %. The correlation study has confirmed that the electronegativity of metal clusters strongly affects the activity and selectivity of the reaction through the synergistic effect between the metal and the support. These findings elucidate the structure–activity–selectivity relationships underlying HDO performance and offer valuable insights for the rational design of selective deoxygenation catalysts targeting lignin-derived compounds.
